book.name: Prevalence of ELLs
book.intro: Our first guiding question is: How prevalent are ELLs in the United States?

chapter.title: Number of ELLs in AEFLA-funded programs in the U.S.
chapter.content:
Let's consider the prevalence of ELLs in the U.S. 

Take a moment to think about and answer the following question:

Consider how many learners were served by adult education programs funded by the Adult Education and Family Literacy Act (AEFLA), Title II of the Workforce Innovation and Opportunity Act (WIOA). AEFLA-funded programs include instruction related to Adult Basic Education (ABE), English Language Acquisition (ELA), Integrated English Literacy and Civics Education (IELCE), and Integrated Education and Training (IET).

In the 2017-2018 program year, how many learners enrolled in AEFLA-funded programs, according to the National Reporting System?

  1. 1,056,487;
  2. 1,389,694;
  3. 2,576,934; or
  4. 5,043,987

When you have decided on your answer, click the forward arrow for the correct answer and the next question.

chapter.title: ELLs served in AEFLA-funded programs
chapter.content:
The correct answer is b. There were 1,389,694 learners served in adult education programs during the 2017-2018 program year.

Now, what percentage of those learners do you think were enrolled specifically in ELA or IELCE programs?

Is it:

  1. 8%
  2. 24%;
  3. 33%; or
  4. 49%

When you have decided on your answer, click the forward arrow for the correct answer.

chapter.title: ELLs served in ELA or IELCE programs
chapter.content:
The number of adult learners enrolled in ELA or IELCE programs may be higher than you think. The answer is d: 49 percent. Nationally, English language and literacy programs are in high demand. In fact, several states and territories had combined enrollment in English language programs (ELA, IELCE) of 60% or higher in the 2017-2018 program year, according to the National Reporting System, including:

  • Nevada, 72%
  • Massachusetts, 65%
  • California, 64%
  • New York, 63%
  • American Samoa, 61%
  • Illinois, 61%
  • Rhode Island, 60%
  • Florida, 60%

These large numbers of ELLs in adult education programs shows that there is real need for serving ELLs, including the ELLs who may have disabilities.

chapter.title: Contributing factors that may make learning English difficult
chapter.content:
Now that we've talked about the prevalence of ELLs in the United States, let's consider:

What can make learning English difficult for ELLs?

There are many contributors that should be considered, including:

  • limited academic skills with the primary language;
  • external problems with work, health, or family;
  • stress or trauma that was experienced early in life;
  • social or cultural identity issues;
  • a mismatch between the instructor style and learner;
  • a lack of school attendance;
  • limited practice outside of the instructional setting; and
  • for some ELLs - undiagnosed learning disabilities that can impact learners’ ability to learn a new language.
